articles.headline: Toning Down the Tweets Just in Case Colleges Pry
articles.snippet: Warned that colleges are increasingly investigating digital histories, high school students are cleaning up their public social media activity.
articles.abstract: Warned that colleges are increasingly investigating digital histories, high school students are cleaning up their public social media activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Admissions officers at Morehouse College in Atlanta were shocked several years ago when a number of high school seniors submitted applications using email addresses containing provocative language.

articles.headline: A Guide to Buying Just About Anything
articles.snippet: This collection of stories provides counsel on buying things that go beyond everyday shopping —from a horse to political change to a longer life.
articles.abstract: This collection of stories provides counsel on buying things that go beyond everyday shopping —from a horse to political change to a longer life.
articles.lead_paragraph: The basics you probably know by now, at least for the things you buy frequently. How to buy a book online. Pick a good apple in the supermarket. Find sneakers that fit.

articles.headline: Senate Report Finds Goldman and JPMorgan Can Influence Commodities
articles.snippet: A Senate panel found that banks assumed a role of such significance in the commodities markets that it became possible for them to influence the prices that consumers pay.
articles.abstract: A Senate panel found that banks assumed a role of such significance in the commodities markets that it became possible for them to influence the prices that consumers pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: A two-year Senate-led investigation is throwing back the curtain on the outsize and sometimes hidden sway that Wall Street banks have gained over the markets for essential commodities like oil, aluminum and coal.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Billboard, Changing the Charts, Will Count Streaming Services
articles.snippet: Billboard and Nielsen SoundScan will start adding streams to the formula behind the Billboard 200.
articles.abstract: Billboard and Nielsen SoundScan will start adding streams to the formula behind the Billboard 200.
articles.lead_paragraph: Streaming music services like Spotify have brought big changes to the music industry. But one important part of the business has not kept up: Billboard’s album chart.

articles.headline: Bringing Sous Vide to the Home Cook
articles.snippet: The cooking-in-a-bag technique that started in restaurants is poised to go mainstream as prices fall for the gadgetry involved.
articles.abstract: The cooking-in-a-bag technique that started in restaurants is poised to go mainstream as prices fall for the gadgetry involved.
articles.lead_paragraph: Appliance manufacturers have lately been building a surge of high-tech, high-end gadgets for our kitchens, but a lot of them are pretty useless. Who needs a refrigerator with a built-in tablet computer, or an oven that can be turned off from afar? My guess is you’d be fine skipping many of these doodads.

articles.headline: Chinese Interests Look to Malaysia for Cheap Iron Ore, and Profits
articles.snippet: CAA Resources, controlled by China, reopened “Iron Hill,” a dormant iron mine in Bukit Besi, Malaysia, and is ramping up production despite the ore’s falling price.
articles.abstract: CAA Resources, controlled by China, reopened “Iron Hill,” a dormant iron mine in Bukit Besi, Malaysia, and is ramping up production despite the ore’s falling price.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUKIT BESI, Malaysia — Giant mining equipment has stripped away the palm trees and other vegetation from a jungle bluff here with a Malay name that translates to “Iron Hill.” Huge power shovels gouge long furrows down cliffs of fuchsia clay, scooping out the shiny black iron ore at their base.

articles.headline: More Than a Battle, Kobani Is a Publicity War
articles.snippet: The fractious Kurdish diaspora has pulled together against ISIS in the hope of creating a homeland in the area that is technically part of Syria.
articles.abstract: The fractious Kurdish diaspora has pulled together against ISIS in the hope of creating a homeland in the area that is technically part of Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURUC, Turkey — Two months after the United States began bombing militants attacking Kobani in northern Syria, the fate of the obscure border town has become the defining battle of the broader contest with the Islamic State — to solidify, or roll back, its borders and ambitions.

articles.headline: New Scrutiny of Goldman’s Ties to the New York Fed After a Leak
articles.snippet: The perceived coziness between the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Wall Street banks has been questioned after a recent leak.
articles.abstract: The perceived coziness between the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Wall Street banks has been questioned after a recent leak.
articles.lead_paragraph: From his desk in Lower Manhattan, a banker at Goldman Sachs thumbed through confidential documents — courtesy of a source inside the United States government.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Ben Protess and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Ebola Response in Liberia Is Hampered by Infighting
articles.snippet: Poor coordination and serious disagreements between Liberian officials and the donors and health agencies fighting the epidemic are hindering results.
articles.abstract: Poor coordination and serious disagreements between Liberian officials and the donors and health agencies fighting the epidemic are hindering results.
articles.lead_paragraph: The global response to the Ebola virus in Liberia is being hampered by poor coordination and serious disagreements between Liberian officials and the donors and health agencies fighting the epidemic, according to minutes of top-level meetings and interviews with participants.

articles.headline: Reaction to Uber Tactics Highlights Tech Journalists’ Fine Line Between Critic and Booster
articles.snippet: Comments by an Uber executive about spying on a tech journalist have roiled the outspoken, competitive and often conflicted group of publications that cover Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: Comments by an Uber executive about spying on a tech journalist have roiled the outspoken, competitive and often conflicted group of publications that cover Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: Monday night, BuzzFeed reported that an Uber executive had considered investigating the private life of the tech journalist Sarah Lacy because of her negative coverage of the company. Ms. Lacy responded almost instantaneously — and she was not happy.

articles.headline: General Motors Is Sued by Arizona for $3 Billion Over Recalls
articles.snippet: The suit is the first major legal action to be taken against the automaker over its record number of vehicle recalls this year.
articles.abstract: The suit is the first major legal action to be taken against the automaker over its record number of vehicle recalls this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The attorney general of Arizona said on Wednesday that the state had filed suit against General Motors, claiming that the automaker had defrauded the state’s consumers of an estimated $3 billion.

articles.headline: Obama, Daring Congress, Acts to Overhaul Immigration
articles.snippet: President Obama displayed years of frustration with congressional gridlock as he asserted the powers of the Oval Office to reshape the nation’s immigration system.
articles.abstract: President Obama displayed years of frustration with congressional gridlock as he asserted the powers of the Oval Office to reshape the nation’s immigration system.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama chose confrontation over conciliation on Thursday as he asserted the powers of the Oval Office to reshape the nation’s immigration system and all but dared members of next year’s Republican-controlled Congress to reverse his actions on behalf of millions of immigrants.

articles.headline: At Senate Airbag Hearing, Evasion and Uncertainty
articles.snippet: The hearing sought to discover why the problem with exploding airbags, linked to at least five deaths, had yet to be solved.
articles.abstract: The hearing sought to discover why the problem with exploding airbags, linked to at least five deaths, had yet to be solved.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ever since automakers began recalling millions of vehicles with defective airbags made by the Takata Corporation in 2008, the company has remained largely silent in the United States.
articles.byline: By Aaron M. Kessler and Hiroko Tabuchi
